summary_comment: The professor is known for high expectations and challenging students to produce professional-level work, but also for tangential teaching and unclear feedback. Students warn against his capstone class due to harsh grading, with low means and maximums on final projects, suggesting overly demanding standards not aligned with student capabilities. Overall, while some find value in the rigor, many advise caution and alternative options.

Ratings.comment: Expects professional level work. Goes on a tangent very often, criticism doesn't make sense most of time because he doesn't actually read a full paragraph at times. If you don't reference a specific appendix, expect that to not exist. If you want a hard time, but learn a lot, take this professor, else, don't.
wtf this guy's ego bigger than the headaches I get for this class

Don't take his capstone class. He grades harshly on final projects (final dem. stats: mean33% & max62%). If you have another professor, you will get an A or B for the same quality work. His expectations were for a 1-2 year project by a group of 10 professionals,not ECE students on a time crunch. OSU is at fault for not monitoring & stand. classes

summary_comment: Professor Sertel is highly regarded for his clarity, engagement, and deep knowledge in teaching ECE courses, particularly ECE 3010 and ECE 3020. Students appreciate his helpfulness during office hours and his efforts to communicate complex material effectively, though some note that the course structure and workload can be challenging. Overall, while his first-time teaching experience occasionally led to some organizational issues, many find him to be an excellent instructor who genuinely cares about his students' understanding

Ratings.comment: Prof. Sertel is the best professor for ECE 3010 and a great person to learn from. He is clear, engaging, fair, and very knowledgeable.
Sertel is a great teacher and a great person. Best option for ECE 3020 at OSU.
Nice, well spoken, funny professor! I liked him a lot and he was a very reasonable grader. His lectures were very good. Lots of homework (and it takes some time), so keep that in mind.

Definetly get the textbook, his lectures are more high level conceptual stuff and the textbook gives helpful examples.  Attendance not mandatory but if you don't go read the textbook.  Very helpful in office hours and clearly cares about the material he is teaching.  Tough material but overall great teacher, would take again.

Kubi is an amazing professor. His lectures were engaging and he does the best job he can communicating the material. Nobody ever showed up to his office hours but a few people, and I got a lot of helpful information there. The 3020 curriculum needs to be rewritten though. No professor has taught it well from what I have heard from friends.

I think Professor Sertel did the best that he could given the fact this was his first time teaching this course. Attending office hours and reading the textbook thoroughly are pretty much mandatory if you want to have a chance at preforming well in his class. At the end of the day it is a 3000 level ECE course, it's not easy content at all.

Prof. Sertel is nice, but it was his first time teaching the class and it was a mess. No graded homeworks, there was supposed to be 3 hw quizzes and a simulation hw but we only got thru 2 quizzes. The exams and quizzes were questions straight out of the textbook, but he does not prioritize doing textbook problems as study material.

It was his first time teaching 3020, and I think he did a pretty good job. I've come away actually retaining so much information. Each chapter he highlighted assigned readings that directly covered material on the tests. The outside course load is light, but you must practice on your own to succeed. Only wish curve methodology was more clear.

Through his first time teaching 3020, his lecture slides were well put together and his classes were really interesting. He uses the textbook for his exams so make sure to study that. Also, make sure to complete the optional (ungraded) homework assignments, they're good practice. Overall, you'll learn a lot, he's worth taking.

This semester was Sertels first at teaching the course so he had to figure out course pace and other logistics. Lecture slides contained useful examples, homework was not graded but helpful. Very knowledgeable and given the opportunity, I think hell improve his teaching of the course (his other course, 3010, reflects that). Book is very important

Not great at communicating lecture material, homework problems dissimilar to the exams and quizzes. Places little emphasis on studying from the book even though all of his questions are derived from it. Lectures aren't helpful at all and learned more on my own. Very confusing grading method / curve used. Homework's ungraded and not helpful.

summary_comment: Dr. Pulcherio has a mixed reputation among students, with some finding her lectures and teaching methods effective and others critical of her understanding of the material and teaching approach. While some praise her as one of the best instructors, others criticize her for lacking depth in her knowledge and for exams that do not align with the review sessions. Her classes are generally considered challenging, particularly due to tough homework and strict grading, but many appreciate her availability and the clarity of her explanations.

Ratings.comment: Clearly doesn't have a good-enough understanding of the material to be teaching it. Doesn't care about the students. Midterm 2 was nothing like the review it was honestly a joke. Not sure how the university let her get this job.
She's terrible.

I had Prof. Pulcherio for both ECE 3040 and 5042, and I highly recommend taking her classes. I enjoyed her teaching style, and her exams are manageable if you do well on the homework and understand the exam review.
straight forward, fair amount of homework, provided study material for exams, helpful when students asked for it

Dr. Pulcherio is a fine lecturer. I thought lectures were very boring and didn't help much. I never cared for an A, and barely studying meant an easy B. It's not too bad; homework is fair, exams are graded quite strictly, and the lab was alright. Again, nothing bad, just dull. Attendance was pretty bad after the syllabus day.

Dr. Pulcherio's lectures were fantastic. The content covered can be tiresome, but she does a good job making things clear. The homeworks can be extremely challenging and can be tough on the grade, but her exams are much easier than the homeworks. If you can work through the HW's, you'll do well on exams.

I did not find the lectures effective at all really, and the dwindling number of attendees probably attests to that. She's not bad, but somehow I thought the content we went over or the approaches to solutions were very unhelpful. Also, tough grading class. Can lose like 20% of you hw grade to missing unit or negative.

One of the best teachers at OSU. I wish there were more like her. 5042 is hard, but without her teaching, it would be impossible to learn anything. My opinion the best teachers I've taken so far is DR. Pulcherio, Dr. Clymer, and Dr. Fernandez (although she doesn't work at osu anymore)

Her lectures are ineffective, and the class materials don't provide much help with the homework. It's more beneficial to watch the MIT OCW lecture videos than attend her classes, which often feel like a waste of time. She essentially rewrites her pre-prepared notes and shares them as post-lecture materials.

This class is online. The class is test heavy. 2 midterms and 1 final. Most of the questions are multiple choice and the word questions are difficult. Homeworks are difficult as well but TA's are helpful.

Homeworks far too often required going to office hours because the lectures were inadequate. The gta was extremely helpful though. The tests had little room for partial credit. Other professor offered multiple attempts for quizzes compared to one. Still you can be successful in this class, but the prof often made it harder than it needed to be.

I had heard from some friends that this was a difficult class but this instructor made it seem very manageable. She is very willing to explain if you any have questions. The homework can be difficult at times but Ece during office hours was a wonderful help. The homework overall is fair and makes sure you are well prepared for exams-which are fair

Dr.Pulcherio makes a very difficult class (especially to non-ECE majors) manageable, and offers so many tools for you to succeed. Her lectures and notes are very helpful and she does everything she can to make sure you understand the material. Being in the online section with 300+ students, she's amazing at teaching it. 10/10

Dr. Pulcherio is a nice professor in power systems. Her exams are all based on the lecture notes and she will help you with homework in office hours. Sometimes she makes mistakes in her lectures but overall she makes the class easy.

Dr. Pulcherio is kind and patient with students that don't grasp the material. She was very helpful after class and in office hours when I had to ask clarification questions. I wish the class had more student engagement and questions to get us thinking. The homework grading often felt unfair due to the rubric structure and all or nothing points.

The online version of the class went quite well. Professor Pulcherio has clear lectures with great follow along notes and good handwriting. The exams are extremely reasonable and closely reflect the homework problems. Couldn't ask for a better professor.

Best professor Ive had at OSU. Shes super helpful with homeworks and always responds to emails. Office hours are awesome and helped with homework a ton. Exams are very reasonable and I was never overwhelmed with course work. 10/10 prof

I am so glad that Professor Pulcherio was my ENGR 1181 professor. Her class was good and easy if you put in the effort. However, if your group is not task-oriented then you might run into problems. Go to class and review the materials and stay focused and you should be fine.

Definitely a great lecturer, she's super attentive to her students and really cares about them doing well. She was always super understanding and took time to explain things in depth for those that didn't follow. She is methodical and a great lecturer. Highly recommend.

It was her first time teaching the class and it went well! The teaching style was a little boring though, tons of derivations were done in class. I wish more example problems were solved instead. She was super helpful outside of class and was willing to schedule 1 on 1 help. Also, extremely pleasant to speak with :)

Hands down one of the best professors I have ever had! She explains things very well, is always helpful in office hours, and her exams are extremely fair. She will go over the homework to double check your answers during office hours. Super patient with students and understanding. Any class she teaches, I would take it in a heartbeat.

Dr. Pulcherio was a great teacher for ECE! She made the difficult (and sometimes boring) material comprehendible. She had very clear and concise expectations. Her homeworks and tests correlated very well. Come to class, do the homework and GO TO OFFICE HOURS. She was SO helpful in office hours and she is very kind.

summary_comment: Professor Arafin is known for his rigorous teaching style, offering challenging exams with minimal partial credit, which makes high scores difficult to achieve. Despite the difficulty, students find the class rewarding, noting significant learning gains and appreciating his organized lectures and willingness to assist via email. The course structure includes a mid-term drop and a substantial final curve, which enhances overall grades.

Ratings.comment: His exams are extremely challenging, and he has little to no partial credit, making scoring well difficult.

This is a tough class, but I feel like I learned a lot! Prof Arafin has super organized lectures, and reading the book is optional, but I actually liked the book and didnt mind reading! He is also very kind and willing to help even over email! One midterm gets dropped and you get a huge curve at the end. I definitely recommend!

summary_comment: Professor Kassas is an exceptional instructor for the graduate-level course 5551, delivering a deep understanding of linear state space systems through rigorous study and engagement. While the course is challenging, his pragmatic approach ensures that students focus on genuine learning rather than grades.

Ratings.comment: Kassas teaches 5551 as a graduate level course. You WILL learn and develop a strong understanding of linear state space systems if you keep up and spend time on the homework and with the book. I recommend you review linear algebra before the class. Fantastic professor, but tough. You get out what you put in, and class interaction is rewarded.

The hardest course I've ever taken but his pragmatism is redeeming. He said something along the lines of: "I've gotten A's in courses without learning a thing, and I've gotten less desirable grades in courses where I've learned lots. Don't worry about the grade because it is what it is."

summary_comment: Professor Zhao is highly regarded for her effective teaching methods, making a challenging course accessible and engaging. Her lectures are clear and supportive, with a focus on student understanding. While the textbook may be less helpful, her dedication and enthusiasm significantly enhance the learning experience.

Ratings.comment: ECE 3030 is a joke. The class consists of a textbook with poor explanations and rather just derivatations. Lecture consists of formula derivations with little to no examples. Be careful of weekly pop quizzes. Office hours with the TA can somewhat be helpful however, Professor Zhao usually doesn't appear in her office hours.

If you have the chance to take 3030 with Prof Zhao, do it! 3030 is supposed to be a hard class but she makes it easy to understand. She cares about her students so much and gets happy when she sees us liking the material. Homeworks are hard, but once you understand them the exams are a breeze. Thank you Professor Zhao <3

summary_comment: The professor has significant issues with poor handwriting and difficulty hearing his voice from the back of the room, leading to boring and poorly explained lectures. Students find the homework and exams challenging and time-consuming, with minimal useful preparation provided. Overall, the professor's teaching quality is low, and students strongly advise avoiding his class.

Ratings.comment: Terrible handwriting. Voice is hard to hear from the back. Boring lectures and does not explain materials well. Long weekly HW. Hides grade for the entire semester. He gave 15-20% curve for each exam (MT1's avg is 45, MT2 is 54, MT 3 is 62). AVOID HIM

Handwriting was the biggest thing for me, even when attending lectures the handwriting made it much harder to learn.  The class itself is not that difficult, the texbook helps a bit and there is infinite material on youtube.

Every comment  below greatly exaggerate his flaws. If these hooligans had gone to office hours, they could have easily succeeded. His bad handwriting, terrible attitude, tendency to come to class unprepared and terrible exams aside, he was a very caring and knowledgeable person. He deserves to be a tenured professor.

Where do I even begin. A man of his age should not have handwriting that bad. He gets hostile when you ask questions that he deems "should be obvious", but in the same breath says to ask questions. He stresses that we need to review homework problems for the exams, but they are extremely different. He does give halfway decent curves though.

Please do not take this class with this professor. He doesn't provide a midterm review for his midterms so you just have to read the textbook entirely and hope you have covered the topics on the exam. His homework is very hard and his exams are harder. Please save your GPA and don't take the class with him.

his handwriting is terrible, all the exams are very difficult and he does not give any useful preparation for the exams other than a 2 page essay explaining why he doesnt want to give practice problems. his lecture notes are incredibly hard to follow and the entire class rests on the ability of the TA. last, he doesnt even let you see your grade.

He provides no useful material for the exams, exams are extremely difficult with the mean at 50%. Homework's are very hard and time consuming and while he emphasizes to look at homework's to help study for exams, you will find out the homework questions have no relation to the test. His handwriting is terrible, no lecture videos. Don't take him pls
no word to say

He doesn't give you enough information to study, sometimes he even tells you to study something specific and then doesn't put it on the exam. He also takes forever to grade, you won't know what grade you have the whole semester. Disorganized lecture, and unclear notes so you can't review them after class. Overall, it is better to wait a semester

- Horrendous Handwriting for Lecture Notes
- Midterm "Review Guides" are just 3 overarching themes so just guess what concepts from the last 4 weeks will be on the test
- Wraps important information in jokes that make no sense bc they are written on paper
- Labs are easy but does not align in the least with lecture
- Means well but can't teach

Benjamin is one of the most unenthusiastic profs I've ever had. He emphasizes reading the textbook for the course which is incredibly dense and filled with a lot of irrelevant information. Has awful handwriting and is the only prof who doesn't record his lectures so you can't go back and listen to what he writes. He's a decent guy but a bad teacher
